DataElement.preferredName: Cytogenetic Analysis of Hematologic Neoplasm Chromosome Band Resolution Value
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Numeric representation of the chromosome band pattern resolution obtained in the hematologic neoplasm chromosome analysis testing.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Cytogenetic Analysis of Hematologic Neoplasm Chromosome Banding Resolution
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A cytogenetic test to define and interpret chromosomal aberrations that occur in neoplastic cells associated with hematologic malignancies._The treatment of chromosomes to reveal characteristic patterns of horizontal bands.  The banding patterns lend each chromosome a distinctive appearance so the 22 pairs of human non-sex chromosomes and the X and Y chromosomes can be identified and distinguished without ambiguity. Banding also permits the recognition of chromosome deletions (lost segments), chromosome duplications (surplus segments) and other types of structural rearrangements of chromosomes._The size of the smallest element that can be separated from neighboring elements.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A cytogenetic test to define and interpret chromosomal aberrations that occur in neoplastic cells associated with hematologic malignancies.

Concepts.definition: A cytogenetic test to define and interpret chromosomal aberrations that occur in neoplastic cells associated with hematologic malignancies.

Property.preferredDefinition: The treatment of chromosomes to reveal characteristic patterns of horizontal bands.  The banding patterns lend each chromosome a distinctive appearance so the 22 pairs of human non-sex chromosomes and the X and Y chromosomes can be identified and distinguished without ambiguity. Banding also permits the recognition of chromosome deletions (lost segments), chromosome duplications (surplus segments) and other types of structural rearrangements of chromosomes.:The size of the smallest element that can be separated from neighboring elements.

Concepts.definition: The treatment of chromosomes to reveal characteristic patterns of horizontal bands.  The banding patterns lend each chromosome a distinctive appearance so the 22 pairs of human non-sex chromosomes and the X and Y chromosomes can be identified and distinguished without ambiguity. Banding also permits the recognition of chromosome deletions (lost segments), chromosome duplications (surplus segments) and other types of structural rearrangements of chromosomes.
The size of the smallest element that can be separated from neighboring elements.
